profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Troy, N.Y., March 22, 1809; attended the common schools; went into business for himself at the age of fifteen; began his financial career as cashier of the Bank of Orleans, Albion, N.Y.; moved to Rochester, N.Y., in 1845; became director and president of numerous banks, railroads, and telegraph and trust companies of Rochester and New York City; delegate to the Whig National Convention at Baltimore in 1852; vice president of the first Republican State convention of New York in 1854; appointed Comptroller of the Currency in 1865; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1867; elected as a Republican to the Thirty-eighth Congress (March 4, 1863-March 3, 1865); was not a candidate for renomination in 1864; Comptroller of the Currency from March 9, 1865, to February 6, 1867; again elected to the Forty-second and Forty-third Congresses (March 4, 1871-March 3, 1875); resumed his former business pursuits; died in Rochester, N.Y., on June 24, 1887; interment in Mount Hope Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: New York (State). Constitutional Convention (1867-1868). Report of Freeman Clarke, from the Committee on Finance, etc., to the Constitutional Convention, in reference to the financial article of the constitution, the enlargement of the locks of the Erie and Oswego Canals, the payment of the state debt without resort to further taxation, and comparative freight business on canals and railroads. [N.p., 1867].

researchRecord.name: In the Freeman Clarke Family Papers, 1812-1929, 8 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers include Freeman Clarke's business correspondence concerning grain and lumber trade at Albion, Bank of Albion, Clarke's Bank, and other Rochester banks, and investments in Rochester, Lockport & Niagara Falls Railroad Company, Genesee Valley Railroad Company, Western Union Telegraph Company, and the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle. Also official correspondence of Freeman Clarke as a Member of Congress and Comptroller of the Currency in the 1860s and 1870s, with emphasis on introduction of national banking system after the Civil War. A register is available in the library and online.
